title: Numbers Chapter 26 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Numbers chapter 26 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Numbers Chapter 26 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Numbers Chapter 26.

questions.question: Who spoke to Moses and Eleazar after the plague?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:1 states that the LORD spoke unto Moses and Eleazar after the plague.

questions.question: What age group was to be counted in the census according to the LORD's command?
options: From twenty years old and upward
From five years old and upward
From thirty years old and upward
From fifteen years old and upward
questions.correctAnswer: From twenty years old and upward
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:2 commands that the sum be taken of all from twenty years old and upward.

questions.question: Where were Moses and Eleazar when they spoke to the Israelites about the census?
options: In the plains of Moab by Jordan near Jericho
questions.correctAnswer: In the plains of Moab by Jordan near Jericho
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:3 specifies the location as the plains of Moab by Jordan near Jericho.

questions.question: Which son of Israel was the eldest mentioned in the census?
questions.correctAnswer: Reuben
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:5 mentions Reuben as the eldest son of Israel.

questions.question: Who were the three sons of Eliab mentioned who opposed Moses and Aaron?
questions.correctAnswer: Nemuel, Dathan, and Abiram
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:9 names Nemuel, Dathan, and Abiram as sons of Eliab who opposed Moses and Aaron.

questions.question: True or False: The children of Korah died when the earth opened its mouth.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:11 states that the children of Korah did not die despite the earth swallowing others.

questions.question: How many were numbered of the Simeonites?
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:14 records that the Simeonites numbered twenty-two thousand two hundred.

questions.question: Which two sons of Judah died in the land of Canaan?
questions.correctAnswer: Er and Onan
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:19 specifies that Er and Onan, sons of Judah, died in the land of Canaan.

questions.question: Who was the father of Machir, the head of a family in Manasseh?
questions.correctAnswer: Manasseh
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:29 states that Machir was the son of Manasseh.

questions.question: Which daughter of Zelophehad is NOT named in the list?
questions.correctAnswer: Sarah
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:33 names Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah as Zelophehad's daughters; Sarah is mentioned as Asher's daughter in 26:46.

questions.question: True or False: The Levites were given an inheritance of land among the children of Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:62 states that the Levites were not numbered among the children of Israel because they had no inheritance among them.

questions.question: What was the total number of the children of Israel counted in this census?
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:51 gives the total number as six hundred thousand and one thousand seven hundred and thirty.

questions.question: According to the LORD's instructions, how was the land to be divided among the tribes?
options: According to the number of names and by lot
questions.correctAnswer: According to the number of names and by lot
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:53-55 explain the land was to be divided according to the number of names and by lot.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'And Nadab and Abihu died, when they offered ______ before the LORD.'
questions.correctAnswer: strange fire
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:61 states Nadab and Abihu died when they offered strange fire before the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: Only Caleb and Joshua survived from those numbered at Sinai.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:65 confirms that only Caleb son of Jephunneh and Joshua son of Nun were left from those numbered at Sinai.

medium.title: Numbers Chapter 26 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Numbers Chapter 26 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with discouragement after facing consequences for past sins. Based on Numbers 26:65, what biblical truth would you share about God's faithfulness and hope?
options: God allows no one to survive after punishment
God remembers and preserves those who remain faithful
Everyone who sins is abandoned by God
Punishment is permanent with no hope for restoration
questions.correctAnswer: God remembers and preserves those who remain faithful
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:65 shows that though most were punished in the wilderness, Caleb and Joshua were preserved because of their faithfulness, demonstrating God's faithfulness and hope for those who trust Him.

questions.question: How does Numbers 26:2 teach us about the importance of responsibility and readiness in spiritual service?
options: All are responsible to be prepared for God's work
Service is optional and not urgent
questions.correctAnswer: All are responsible to be prepared for God's work
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:2 commands taking a census of all able men from twenty years old up, emphasizing readiness and responsibility of every capable person to serve God faithfully.

questions.question: A believer is feeling isolated and unsure how to serve the church. Based on Numbers 26:57-59, what biblical principle about family and service can encourage them?
options: Service is limited to only a few chosen people
Family lineage influences service roles but all can contribute
Only priests from Aaron's line can serve God
No family connection is needed to serve
questions.correctAnswer: Family lineage influences service roles but all can contribute
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:57-59 details the Levite families and their roles, showing God assigns service according to family but implies every member has a part, encouraging believers to serve within their gifts and contexts.

questions.question: How does the census in Numbers 26 emphasize the biblical virtue of stewardship in managing God's blessings?
options: Counting people is unnecessary for stewardship
Knowing God's people allows fair distribution and responsible management
Stewardship only applies to money, not people
God's blessings cannot be managed or counted
questions.correctAnswer: Knowing God's people allows fair distribution and responsible management
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:51-56 shows God instructing Moses to count the people so land inheritance could be fairly divided, teaching stewardship requires careful, responsible management of blessings.

questions.question: A church leader is seeking guidance on humility and contentment in ministry. Based on Numbers 26:54-56, what principle can be applied?
options: Ministers should seek the greatest rewards
Each receives according to what God has assigned, whether more or less
Comparison among believers leads to blessing
Inheritances are earned by human effort alone
questions.correctAnswer: Each receives according to what God has assigned, whether more or less
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:54-56 explains land was divided by lot, with more given to many and less to few, teaching humility and contentment with God's sovereign distribution.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compare their spiritual gifts with others. What does Numbers 26 teach about God’s allocation of gifts and roles?
options: God gives gifts based on favoritism
God assigns roles and blessings according to His wisdom and purpose
questions.correctAnswer: God assigns roles and blessings according to His wisdom and purpose
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:54-56 and the detailed families' census reveal God’s sovereign distribution of roles and blessings, teaching believers to trust His wisdom rather than compare.

questions.question: How does the account of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram in Numbers 26:9-11 teach us about the dangers of rebellion and the importance of obedience?
options: Rebellion leads to destruction, obedience brings life
Rebellion is a way to gain power
questions.correctAnswer: Rebellion leads to destruction, obedience brings life
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:9-11 recounts how Korah and his followers were swallowed by the earth for rebelling, showing the severe consequences of disobedience and the need for submission to God’s authority.

questions.question: True or False: Numbers 26 shows that all the Levites were counted with the rest of Israel for land inheritance purposes.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:62 states the Levites were counted separately and were not numbered among the children of Israel for land inheritance because they had no inheritance among them.

questions.question: True or False: Numbers 26 teaches that spiritual leadership requires both family heritage and personal obedience to God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:57-61 describes the Levitical families and mentions Nadab and Abihu who died for offering strange fire, highlighting that heritage alone is not enough without obedience.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Numbers 26:33, Zelophehad had no sons but had daughters named Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and _____.
questions.correctAnswer: Tirzah
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:33 lists the daughters of Zelophehad as Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah, showing God's provision for inheritance through daughters when no sons are present.

questions.question: How does the detailed census and family listing in Numbers 26 encourage us in the virtue of faithfulness in family and community life?
options: God values and remembers each family and individual
Only leaders matter in God's plan
questions.correctAnswer: God values and remembers each family and individual
questions.explanation: The extensive family records in Numbers 26 (e.g., verses 5-50) demonstrate God's care for each family line, encouraging believers to be faithful in their family roles and community life.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged about their small role in the church. Based on the land inheritance teaching in Numbers 26:54-56, what biblical truth can you share?
options: God assigns importance based on size alone
Every role, whether large or small, is part of God's plan
questions.correctAnswer: Every role, whether large or small, is part of God's plan
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:54-56 teaches that land was divided by lot according to the number of people, with both more and less given, showing that God values all roles regardless of size.

questions.question: Based on Numbers 26:63, what spiritual discipline is demonstrated through the census and recording of Israel’s tribes?
questions.correctAnswer: Accountability and remembrance
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:63 shows Moses and Eleazar numbering the people, illustrating the spiritual discipline of accountability and remembering God’s people and their place in His plan.

questions.question: How does Numbers 26:61 warn believers about the importance of reverence and holiness in approaching God?
options: Fire is a symbol of anger only
questions.correctAnswer: Irreverence leads to serious consequences
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:61 mentions that Nadab and Abihu died when they offered strange fire before the LORD, warning believers to approach God with reverence and holiness.

questions.question: How does the census in Numbers 26 teach us about perseverance through trials and God's provision for His people?
options: God preserves a remnant who remain faithful
questions.correctAnswer: God preserves a remnant who remain faithful
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:64-65 explains that none of the previous generation survived the wilderness except Caleb and Joshua, illustrating God's preservation of a faithful remnant through trials.

hard.title: Numbers Chapter 26 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Numbers Chapter 26.

questions.question: What was the primary reason for the census taken in Numbers 26?
options: To prepare for the division of the Promised Land
To determine the number of Levites for priestly duties
To record the genealogy of Moses and Aaron
To count the number of people who died in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: To prepare for the division of the Promised Land
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:52-56 shows that the census was taken to allocate the land inheritance according to the number of names.

questions.question: Which two leaders were commanded by the LORD to conduct the census in Numbers 26?
questions.correctAnswer: Moses and Eleazar
questions.explanation: In Numbers 26:1, the LORD spoke to Moses and Eleazar the son of Aaron to take the census.

questions.question: In Numbers 26, which family is noted to have survived the judgment that swallowed up Korah and his company?
questions.correctAnswer: The children of Korah
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:11 states that the children of Korah did not die, even though Korah and his company were swallowed by the earth.

questions.question: Which tribe had the highest number of men able to go to war according to the census in Numbers 26?
questions.correctAnswer: Judah
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:22 records Judah with 76,500 men, the highest among the tribes listed.

questions.question: How does the census of Numbers 26 relate to the promise made to Abraham about his descendants?
options: It shows the fulfillment of God's promise of numerous descendants
It contradicts the promise because the numbers are low
It focuses only on the Levites, unrelated to Abraham's promise
It was meant to prepare for exile, not fulfillment
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the fulfillment of God's promise of numerous descendants
questions.explanation: The large numbers in Numbers 26:51 reflect the fulfillment of God's promise to Abraham about his seed being as numerous as the stars (Genesis 15:5).

questions.question: Which daughters are mentioned in Numbers 26 as the heirs in the absence of a male heir?
options: Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah
Sarah, Rebekah, Leah, Rachel, and Miriam
Dinah, Zipporah, Deborah, Huldah, and Anna
Esther, Ruth, Abigail, Bathsheba, and Judith
questions.correctAnswer: Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:33 names the daughters of Zelophehad who inherited because he had no sons.

questions.question: True or False: The Levites were included in the general census for land inheritance in Numbers 26.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:62 explains the Levites were not numbered among the children of Israel for inheritance because they had no land allotment.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the enumeration of families and their descendants in Numbers 26, reflecting ancient Near Eastern practices?
questions.correctAnswer: Historical annalistic listing
questions.explanation: The detailed listing of families and numbers reflects the ancient Near Eastern annalistic style of recording census and genealogies as a historical record (Numbers 26:5-50).

questions.question: How does the census in Numbers 26 foreshadow the New Testament concept of inheritance?
options: Land inheritance parallels spiritual inheritance through Christ
It predicts the division of the church into tribes
It prefigures the establishment of the Levitical priesthood
It symbolizes the judgment of nations
questions.correctAnswer: Land inheritance parallels spiritual inheritance through Christ
questions.explanation: The allocation of land by number in Numbers 26:54-56 typologically prefigures the spiritual inheritance believers receive in Christ as heirs (cf. Ephesians 1:11).

questions.question: Which sons of Joseph are detailed in Numbers 26, and what significance do they hold in Israelite tribal identity?
options: Manasseh and Ephraim, representing the double portion inheritance
Reuben and Simeon, as the eldest tribes
Gad and Asher, as warrior clans
Dan and Naphtali, as coastal tribes
questions.correctAnswer: Manasseh and Ephraim, representing the double portion inheritance
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:28 names Manasseh and Ephraim, Joseph’s sons who each became tribes, signifying Joseph’s double portion inheritance (cf. Genesis 48).

questions.question: What is the significance of the mention of Nadab and Abihu in Numbers 26 in relation to priestly legitimacy?
options: They died offering unauthorized fire, illustrating the importance of obedience
They became high priests after Aaron
They led the Israelites into battle
They were censured for refusing the census
questions.correctAnswer: They died offering unauthorized fire, illustrating the importance of obedience
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:61 recalls Nadab and Abihu’s death for offering strange fire, emphasizing priestly obedience and holiness.

questions.question: True or False: Caleb and Joshua were the only men from the previous generation counted in the first census who survived to be counted in Numbers 26.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:64-65 notes that all from the previous census had died except Caleb and Joshua, fulfilling the LORD's judgment.

questions.question: Which verse in Numbers 26 highlights the cultural practice of inheritance by lot among the tribes of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Numbers 26:55
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:55 states the land shall be divided by lot according to the tribes, reflecting a cultural method of land allocation.

questions.question: What is the significance of the daughters of Zelophehad in Numbers 26 for biblical inheritance laws?
options: They established a precedent for female inheritance in the absence of sons
They were excluded from inheritance rights
They became priestesses in the tabernacle
They led a rebellion against Moses
questions.correctAnswer: They established a precedent for female inheritance in the absence of sons
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:33 mentions these daughters, linking to the legal precedent in Numbers 27:1-11 for daughters inheriting if no sons existed.

questions.question: How does the census in Numbers 26 reflect the theological theme of covenant faithfulness?
options: The renewed numbering shows God's ongoing commitment to Israel despite previous failures
It shows God's rejection of the generation that disobeyed
It emphasizes the Levites as the only faithful tribe
It focuses on military strength rather than covenant
questions.correctAnswer: The renewed numbering shows God's ongoing commitment to Israel despite previous failures
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:51-65 indicates this census follows the plague, showing God's faithfulness to preserve a new generation to inherit the promise.

theological.title: Numbers Chapter 26 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Numbers Chapter 26 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the primary purpose of the census taken in Numbers 26?
options: To determine the number of men able to go to war
To assign Levites their priestly duties
To record the names of all Israelite women
To count the livestock of the tribes
questions.correctAnswer: To determine the number of men able to go to war
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:2 states the census was to count all Israelite males aged twenty and above able to go to war. This aligns with the Old Testament practice of numbering the fighting men (Exodus 30:12; Deuteronomy 20:3-4) and finds a New Testament echo in the spiritual warfare imagery (Ephesians 6:10-18).

questions.question: Who were the leaders instructed by the LORD to conduct the census in Numbers 26?
questions.correctAnswer: Moses and Eleazar the priest
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:1 shows that God spoke to Moses and Eleazar, son of Aaron the priest, to take the census. Moses as God's mediator and Eleazar as the priest signify the unity of civil and priestly authority, reflecting God's order in leadership (Hebrews 3:1-6; Numbers 3:32).

questions.question: Which tribe's men are noted as not having died in the wilderness despite the rebellion associated with Korah?
questions.correctAnswer: The children of Korah
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:11 states that the children of Korah did not die during the rebellion where Korah and others were swallowed by the earth (Numbers 26:9-10). This demonstrates God's justice and mercy, sparing some who remained faithful, prefiguring Christ's intercession (Romans 8:34) and God's preservation of His elect (John 10:27-29).

questions.question: According to Numbers 26, what was the basis for dividing the land among the tribes of Israel?
options: According to the number of names in each tribe
Based on each tribe's military strength
By the order of the tribes' founding fathers
By the merit of each family's faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: According to the number of names in each tribe
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:53-54 explains that the land inheritance was to be divided according to the number of names in each tribe, showing God's principle of equitable distribution based on His sovereign counting. This reflects God's justice (Psalm 89:14) and foreshadows New Testament teachings on stewardship and rewards (Matthew 25:14-30).

questions.question: What theological significance can be derived from the deaths of Nadab and Abihu mentioned in Numbers 26?
options: God's holiness demands reverence in worship
God rewards those who offer strange fire
Priestly duties can be performed without fear
questions.correctAnswer: God's holiness demands reverence in worship
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:61 recounts Nadab and Abihu dying for offering strange fire, emphasizing God's holiness (Isaiah 6:3), the necessity of proper worship (Hebrews 12:28-29), and the seriousness of sin before a holy God (Romans 3:23). This event prefigures Christ's perfect atonement enabling true worship (John 4:23-24).

questions.question: Which two men were the only survivors from the generation numbered in the wilderness census, as stated in Numbers 26?
questions.correctAnswer: Caleb and Joshua
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:65 emphasizes that only Caleb son of Jephunneh and Joshua son of Nun survived from the wilderness generation, illustrating God's faithfulness to those who trust Him (Hebrews 11:32-40) and the concept of divine judgment on unbelief (Hebrews 3:16-19). Their survival prefigures the faithful remnant theme throughout Scripture (Romans 11:5).

questions.question: What does the detailed listing of families and tribes in Numbers 26 teach about God's covenant relationship with Israel?
options: God maintains a structured community based on covenant promises
God favors only the largest tribes
God shows partiality to certain families
God disregards family lineage in His plan
questions.correctAnswer: God maintains a structured community based on covenant promises
questions.explanation: The genealogical and tribal structure in Numbers 26 (e.g., verses 5-51) illustrates God's orderly covenant relationship with Israel, emphasizing His faithfulness to promises given to the patriarchs (Genesis 17:7) and the importance of identity and inheritance in His plan (Acts 7:8). This structure foreshadows the unity and diversity in the body of Christ (1 Corinthians 12:12-27).

questions.question: Why were the Levites not numbered among the other tribes in the census of Numbers 26?
options: Because they had no inheritance among the children of Israel
Because they were the smallest tribe
Because they were not part of the covenant
questions.correctAnswer: Because they had no inheritance among the children of Israel
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:62 clarifies that Levites were not numbered with the other tribes because they had no land inheritance, highlighting their unique role as priests and mediators (Deuteronomy 10:8-9; Hebrews 7:23-28). This teaches about God's provision for spiritual leadership distinct from material inheritance (1 Peter 2:9).

questions.question: What is the significance of Zelophehad's daughters being named in Numbers 26?
options: It highlights the provision for inheritance rights of daughters
It shows a failure to produce male heirs
It indicates a separate tribe formed by women
It suggests daughters could not inherit property
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights the provision for inheritance rights of daughters
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:33 notes that Zelophehad had no sons but daughters, reflecting God's justice in ensuring inheritance rights for daughters (Numbers 27:1-11). This points to God's care for equity and foreshadows New Testament teachings on inheritance in Christ for all believers (Galatians 3:29; Romans 8:17).

questions.question: How does the census in Numbers 26 reinforce the doctrine of God's sovereignty in salvation history?
options: God directs the numbering and inheritance by His sovereign will
The census was random and based on human decision
The inheritance was given to those who demanded it
Salvation was dependent on tribal size
questions.correctAnswer: God directs the numbering and inheritance by His sovereign will
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:53-56 shows God commanding the division of the land by lot according to names, emphasizing His sovereign control over Israel's history and inheritance. This aligns with the biblical truth that God ordains all events (Proverbs 16:33; Romans 8:28), ensuring His redemptive plan unfolds according to His purpose (Ephesians 1:11).

questions.question: What doctrinal truth is underscored by the death of the rebellious leaders Dathan and Abiram as recorded in Numbers 26?
options: God's judgment on rebellion against His appointed leaders
Rebellion is often overlooked by God
God does not punish sin immediately
questions.correctAnswer: God's judgment on rebellion against His appointed leaders
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:9-10 records that Dathan and Abiram, who rebelled against Moses and Aaron, were swallowed by the earth as a sign of God's judgment. This reveals God's holiness and justice (Psalm 7:11), the seriousness of opposing His chosen servants (Hebrews 13:17), and prefigures Christ's ultimate authority (Matthew 28:18).

questions.question: What does the census in Numbers 26 reveal about the fulfillment of God's promise to Abraham regarding numerous descendants?
options: The children of Israel were numbered at over 600,000 men able to go to war
The tribes were small and insignificant
Only a few families remained from the patriarchs
The promise was unfulfilled at this time
questions.correctAnswer: The children of Israel were numbered at over 600,000 men able to go to war
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:51 reports the total census as 601,730 men, fulfilling God's promise to Abraham that his descendants would be as numerous as the stars (Genesis 15:5). This demonstrates God's faithfulness to covenant promises (Romans 4:20-21) and prefigures the spiritual multitude redeemed by Christ (Revelation 7:9).

questions.question: How does Numbers 26 connect with the doctrine of ecclesiology regarding the unity and diversity of God's people?
options: It details the distinct tribes and families forming one covenant community
It promotes tribal divisions and disunity
It excludes Levites from the community
It focuses only on individuals, not groups
questions.correctAnswer: It details the distinct tribes and families forming one covenant community
questions.explanation: The enumeration of tribes and families in Numbers 26 (e.g., verses 12-50) reveals God's design for a unified yet diverse people, prefiguring the New Testament Church composed of many members in one body (1 Corinthians 12:12-27). This highlights God's providence in organizing His people for worship and mission (Ephesians 4:4-6).

questions.question: What role does Eleazar the priest play in Numbers 26, and what does this indicate about priestly function in Israel's covenant community?
options: He assists Moses in numbering the people, demonstrating priestly mediation
He leads the army into battle
He is the sole leader of the tribes
He performs sacrifices alone without Moses
questions.correctAnswer: He assists Moses in numbering the people, demonstrating priestly mediation
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:1-3 shows Eleazar assisting Moses in conducting the census, reflecting the priestly role as mediator between God and Israel (Leviticus 10:3; Hebrews 7:23-28). This cooperation underscores the integration of spiritual leadership in communal governance, anticipating Christ's eternal priesthood (Hebrews 4:14).

questions.question: Which attribute of God is most clearly demonstrated by the instructions to divide the inheritance by lot among the tribes in Numbers 26?
questions.correctAnswer: God's justice and impartiality
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:55-56 explains that land was divided by lot according to the tribes, illustrating God's justice and impartiality in distributing inheritance. This reflects biblical themes of divine fairness (Deuteronomy 10:17), the righteousness of God (Psalm 89:14), and God's sovereign governance over His people (Romans 3:4).

questions.question: What does the census in Numbers 26 teach about the consequences of unbelief and disobedience in the wilderness generation?
options: None of the men numbered in the first census survived except Caleb and Joshua
All the men numbered were allowed to enter the promised land
Unbelief had no impact on inheritance
questions.correctAnswer: None of the men numbered in the first census survived except Caleb and Joshua
questions.explanation: Numbers 26:64-65 reveals that none of the men numbered in the wilderness census survived except Caleb and Joshua, illustrating God's judgment on unbelief and disobedience (Hebrews 3:16-19). This underscores the seriousness of faith and obedience in the covenant community (James 2:14-26) and highlights God's holiness and justice (Psalm 7:11).
